1.32.text:
Parking in a tight spot is 
the bugbear of every driver.

5.57.text:
And it's not just that narrow spaces 
can make it hard to get out of the car.

9.90.text:
They can also leave you with scrapes 
and dents that are expensive to repair.

14.80.text:
So imagine a car that 
does the dirty work itself.

18.61.text:
Engineers at Ford have 
developed the self-parking car.

22.78.text:
It first finds a parking space 
and then manoeuvres into it.

26.55.text: The driver doesn't even need to be inside.

29.66.text:
Researchers have now succeeded 
in installing the technology in a real car.

34.22.text:
The next step is to make it available to the
drivers as a feature on a production vehicle.

40.48.text:
With perpendicular parking it's trying to
help someone squeeze into that tight space,

44.99.text:
and allows them to have some automated help
within their vehicle to help them achieve

50.51.text:
a driving manoeuvre that they're going to
have to do frequently in their lives.

54.72.text:
It's estimated that there are more than 30
million off-street parking spaces in Europe.

59.63.text:
And although average car width has increased
by 16% over the past 20 years, many parking

65.46.text: spaces are still the same size.

68.82.text:
Which means the new technology is also 
useful when leaving a space. The motorist doesn't

73.24.text:
have to squeeze into the car. They just press
a button and the car drives out itself.
